title: National Geographic Redesign
content:
I have been given the task of proposing a redesign of national geographic magazine for my junior typography class. I’m trying to decide on a new type face for the banner title that has the same presence and authority as the current Times New Roman Condensed, but in a sans. Any suggestions?

 [‹ Type Battle 23: Typographic Love Child](http://web.archive.org/web/20081106044925/http:/typophile.com/battle23 "Go to previous forum topic") [type/letterhead design ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081106044925/http:/typophile.com/node/44756 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Grant Elliott

comments.content: Asking others — I guess this is homework 2.0?

Hi Grant.

I’d recommend OPTIMA.

Good luck!

- Manuel
That’s like your painting professor asking you to repaint the Mona Lisa.

Try a radical approach, maybe Helvetica Condensed.  
\>\_
Actually National Geographic uses a sans for pretty much all of it’s branding except the magazine masthead. Take a look at their website.
Take a look at Basalt and Magma by Sumner Stone.

Choose a couple reliable workhorse typefaces and focus on designing the magazine: Structure, grid, color, photo, etc. Don’t waste time looking for a flashy face to save the day.
